coredata.dc:title: Molecular oxygen on metals
coredata.dc:creator: Hellsing, Bo
Gao, Shiwu
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The chemisorbed state of molecular oxygen on Cu(100) and Ni(100) is investigated using a semi-empirical embedded cluster scheme. The antibonding π* orbital of oxygen will gain charge corresponding to almost complete filling of this state, predominantly by substrate s and d electrons for Cu and NI, respectively. For Ni, the charge transfer to π* is less efficient as the hybridization with the d band is stronger. Furthermore, the d—π hybridization reduces the occupancy of the bonding π state, in particular for Cu, for which this hybridization is stronger. Our results are consistent with experimental observations.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 187, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 November 1991 1. Introduction During the past few years an increasing effort is focused on the understanding of the dissociation dy- namics of oxygen on metals. Recently, results from detailed experimental studies of the system 02/ Pt( 111) have been published [1,2]. In comparison with the system H2/metal [3 6], the underlying mechanism is not well understood, In the case of ox- ygen, the existence of a chemisorbed molecular state, which seems to be absent for hydrogen on low index surfaces, makes the interpretations of the experi- mental data more difficult [1,2]. According to the molecular beam studies by Renter and Mullins 12], the oxygen molecule is temporarily trapped in a chemisorbed molecular state even at rather high in- cidence kinetic energies (~ 1 eV ) - This conclusion was based on studies of the thermal desorption spec- trum of the reaction product C02, formed at low sur- face temperatures in the reaction 0/02 + C0 ~ CO2. The same spectrum is obtained when 02 has been predissociated or supplied by a supersonic beam of an energy less than about 1 eV. These results indicate that a detailed understanding of the molecularly chemisorbed state is important. The chemisorbed molecular state has been studied experimentally at low temperatures (T~ 100 K), us- ing different methods. The vibrational frequency of the internal stretch mode has been measured by EELS for 02 on some metal surfaces. According to these measurements, the results fall into two frequency re- gions. For the noble metal surfaces, like Ag( 110) and Cu (110), the measured frequencies are 630 [7] and 660 cm [8], respectively. For the transition metal surfaces Pt(lll), Pd(ll1) and Cr(llO), the cor- responding values are 870 [9], 850 [10] and 1020 cm [111. These results indicate a larger redshift for 02 on noble metal surfaces than on transition metal surfaces. However, a more careful analysis of 02/Pt( 111) and 02/Pd( 111), shows the existence of an additional intermediate frequency of 700 [12] and 650 cm [10], respectively. In addition to the information of electron struc- ture and internal 02 bond length obtained by pho- toemission [13], Auger spectroscopy [13] and UV photochernistry [14], the NEXAFS measurements [15,16] have revealed information of the unoccu- pied part of the density of states. It seems clear that for the chemisorbed molecule, the bond length is larger for 02 on Ag(l 10) than on Pt(l II) and that part of the 02 antibonding resonance, at, is found above the Fermi level for Pt (111), which is not the case for 02/Ag(ll0) [15]. From a theoretical point of view, the chemisorbed state of the oxygen molecule has been studied on sev- eral metal substrates by extensive cluster configu- ration interaction (Cl) calculations, eg. 02/Ni( 100) [l7],02/Ag(ll0) [18] andO2/Cu(OOl) [19].In these three calculations the chemisorbed molecule is found to be oriented parallel to the surface, which 0009-2614/91/S 03.50 1991 Elsevier Science Publishers BY. All rights reserved. 137 Molecular oxygen on metals Bo Heilsing and Shiwu Gao institute of Theoretical Physics. Chalmers University of Technology, 8-4)2 96 G.tleborg, Sweden Received 29 August 1991 The chemisorbed state of molecular oxygen on Cu( 100) and Ni( 100) is investigated using a semi-empirical embedded cluster scheme. The antibonding z~ orbital of oxygen will gain charge corresponding to almost complete filling of this state, predomi- nantly by substrate s and d electrons for Cu and Ni, respectively. For Ni, the charge transfer to 11* is less efficient as the hybridi- zation with the d band is stronger. Furthermore, the d rr hybridization reduces the occupancy of the bonding it stale, in particular for Cu, for which this hybridization is stronger. Our results are consistent with experimental observations. Volume 187, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 November 1991 experimentally has been observed for 02/Ag (110) and 02/Pt(lll) [15,16]. For Ni(lOO) and Ag( 110), the interpretations of the calculations are quite similar concerning the redistribution of the charge densities. Charge is removed from a1 to the substrate and charge is transferred from the sub- strate to the anti-bonding it ~ orbital. In the case of Ni(100), a7 is the most important part of itt for the charge transfer [17]. The d states of the substrate are found to play a minor role in the molecule surface interaction, and for Ni( 100) it is surprisingly found that the d states do not participate even when the oxygen molecule is placed in the on-top configuration [17]. This con- clusion is questionable because there are abundant surface states on Ni (100), which are sharply peaked below the Fermi level. These surface d states have been shown to play an essential role in the interac- tion and in the charge transfer for an adsorbate on the surface [20]. In this Letter we present results from an embed- ded-cluster calculation of 02/Ni and O2jCu to study the chemisorbed state of the oxygen molecule. We find that the d band is important for the interaction and for the charge transfer. These results are in con- trast to previous CI free metal cluster calculations, where the s electrons of the substrate are not prop- erly described. In the case of atomic oxygen chem- isorption (0/Ni( 100)), it is well known that the 2p state of oxygen is predominantly interacting with the 4s, 4p states of Ni [21]. Regarding the density of states, the 2p resonance is found well below the d band [21], while for 02/Ni( 100), the a resonance appears just in the d band. Before outlining some details of the calculation scheme, we want to point out that in this work we are mainly interested in obtaining a qualitative un- derstanding of the chemisorbed molecular state of oxygen on metals and to hopefully resolve the dif- ferent properties of this state for noble metal and transition metal surfaces. We have chosen the sur- faces Ni(l00) and Cu(100) in order to find the key parameters responsible for this difference. 2. Calculation In this calculation we employ the embedded-clus ter scheme, which is described in detail in ref [20]. Briefly, the electronic states of the chemisorbed sys- tem is expanded in the basis of localized metal d or- bitals, jd>, plane waves, 1k>, and thechemicallyac- tive orbitals of the adsorbate, I a>. The free electrons of the metal are represented by plane wave states of the electron gas instead of local s orbitals as in usual cluster calculations. By projecting the global wave- function of the molecular orbitals into a center clus- ter, the unphysical effects introduced by a free clus- ter boundary and the improper description of the substrate free electron states are removed. This treat- ment is essential to the electron transfer between the adsorbate and the metal substrate [20]. The bulk part of the calculation is to solve the ei- genvaluc problem (H,1 41)cj=0. (1) The lower index refers to the basis I a>, Id) and 1k>, ~, determines the energy spectrum and Oj are the cor- responding coefficients in the expansion of the global cluster wavefunctions. The non-diagonal elements, ~ Haa~ and Hdk are determined according to the parametrization given by Harrison [22,23]. The nu- merical values of the diagonal elements referring to the local orbitals, a> and Id>, are selected from ex- perimental data. They are further adjusted self-con- sistently according to the charge transfer, i.e. H0= I? + U1tsn, [24]. In the present calculation of 02/metal, we have evaluated the overlap matrix ele- ments <a 1k> numerically in order to properly de- scribe the interaction between the directional 2p or- bitals of the oxygen atom and the substrate, i.e. the H~k matrix elements [20]. We find that the 2s orbital of the oxygen molecule is not important for the study of charge transfer. Lin- ear combinations of the 2p orbitals of the molecule will form the molecular orbitals, 3c5, lan, lit5 and 3a~ The bonding orbital tic, in the following de- noted it, and the antibonding orbital lit5, denoted a , are the chemically active molecular orbitals for the chemisorbed state of the oxygen molecule, when considering charge transfer. In the free molecule cal- culation, the parametrized matrix elements, 11aa are adjusted to reproduce the free oxygen molecule spectrum. We choose a 30 atom cluster to describe the sub- 138 Volume 187, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 November 1991 z I 0 0 0 0 0 0 Fig. I. 02/M30 cluster, representing 02/Cu(100) and 02/ Ni( 100) in the calculation. In the lower left corner the direction of the coordinates, x, y and r, is defined. 0 strates, Ni(l00) and Cu(lO0) (see fig. I). The 02 molecule is parallel to the surface and centered on a surface atom (on top site) and the center cluster [20] is formed by the nine substrate atoms closest to the oxygen molecule. The R0_0 value can be estimated from experiments [13,15]. Based on these experi- mental data we have chosen the value R0_0= 2.50 au. As the z distance cannot be determined experi- mentally we have chosen z= 3.30 au, which refers to the optimal distance in an 02Ni3 calculation [25]. 3. Results In the gas phase, the two components of it and ir~ perpendicular to the molecular axis are degenerate with occupancies of four and two electrons, respec- tively. However, when the molecule is chemisorbed with the molecular axis parallel to the surface, the z components (see fig. 1), it~ and ic~, will interact more strongly with the surface compared to the y component, it1 and itt. This difference in interaction between the perpendicular and parallel components gives rise to a splitting of the it and 7I ~ state. For 02/ Cu( 100) (lower part of fig. 2), the two twin peaks are clearly seen. When discussing the general features of charge transfer in terms of occupancies of the it and it~ states, Fig. 2. 02/Cu( 100): projected density of states for the surface metal atom just below the oxygen molecule (upper figure) and for one of the adsorbed oxygen atoms, p~ (s), (lower figure) as a function of energy. po(~) is p,(~) for the clean surface. The two vertical arrows in the lower figure indicate the position of the it state (to the left) and it~ state (to the right) for the free oxygen molecule. we refer to the integrated projected density of states associated with the three oxygen molecular orbitals ~ and 1i ~.. The results of the calculations show that the molecule metal interaction gives rise to metal to ~ charge transfer and to a reduced occupancy of the molecular it state. The occupancy decrease of the it state is caused by redistribution of charge, due to hy- bridization with the d band. This is in agreement with the interpretation of earlier calculations 117,18]. The it and it~K level positions in the gas phase are indi- cated by the vertical arrows in the lower part of fig. 2 0 y 1.5 o 0 0 S oxygen o o 1st layer 0 2nd layer x X 3d layer 0.5 0.6 0.4 0.2 0 -20 -15 -10 -5 0 ~ [eV] 139 Volume 187, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 November 1991 2 and fig. 3. The peak of the it resonance is found just below the Fermi level while the it resonance is found at lower energies. The occupancies of the it and it ' resonances shown in table 1 are derived in an approximative way. The approximation is based on the fact that the main fea- tures of the a and it ' resonances are well separated in energy. Therefore, an intermediate energy be- tween it and ir~ is chosen, below which the adsorbate projected density of states, p0(e), refers to it and above to it '. The a and it occupancies are then ob- tained by integrating the two separate energy re- gions. Due to this approximation, the numbers in ta- ble I are not quantitatively reliable, but rather indicate the trend when comparing the trends for Cu and Ni. Table 1 The charge transfer between the molecule and the metal surfaces Cu(l00) and Ni(l00). In the second column, the total charge transfer from the metal to the molecules (positive sign) is shown, The details of this charge transfer are presented in terms of its parallel and perpendicular (relative 10 the surface plane) contri- butions from the states of a and a character, respectively. In the third column the total charge transfer from the molecule to the metal (negative sign) is shown. Furthermore, the relative contri- bution of the metal d and s states is shown 02 Metal 02/Cu(100) 02/Ni(lOO) An 1.65 1.61 An 1.65 1.61 02/Cu(l00) 02/Ni(l00) An~ 0.29 0.17 An,,, 0.24 0.07 And! (And+An,) 92% 93% 02/Cu(I00) 02/Ni( 100) An,,.~ 1.10 0.94 An,,; 1.07 0.93 AndJ(And+An,) 30% 93% In order to test the sensitivity of our results to the cbosen configuration, we have also considered the configurations (all in atomic units), (R0M, z) r(2.28, 3.97) and (2.72, 2.97). In the first case, where R0~ equals the gas phase value, about two electrons are transferred to the it ' state and the hy- bridization between the metal and molecular states is small. The second configuration corresponds to an almost disssociated molecule, where the it bond is nearly broken and bonds between the individual ox- ygen atoms and the metal surface atoms are formed. From this we conclude that the chosen configura- tion, (R0_0, z) = (2.50, 3.30) is reasonable for a qualitative study of the chemisorbed state of the ox- ygen molecule on Cu(l00) and Ni(l00). 3,1. 02/Cu(100) In the chemisorbed state of 02 on Cu(l00), the d band is located approximately between the it and it ' resonances. The results shown in the upper part of fig. 2 indicate that the d band of Cu is broadened due to hybridization with the molecular states, o The interaction between the a state and the sur face states results in the formation of hybridized d it1 and d a1~ states. These states form the resonances labelled it1 and it 1 in the lower part of fig. 2. Ac- 2.5 1.5 0.5 0 0.9 0.8 0.7 0.6 0.5 0.4 0.3 0.2 0. 0 -20 -5 -15 -tO c [eV] Fig. 3. 02/Ni( 100); as in fig. 2. 140 Volume 187, number 1,2 CHEMtCAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 November 1991 tually, it1 refers to the hybridized bonding d it1 states, while it~ refers to hybridized antibonding d it~. states. The two peaks at about 10 and 8.5 eV correspond to the bonding d.-4 states and anti- bonding d it1 states, respectively. The consequence of the d ir hybridization is a reduction of the oc- cupancy of the it state and an increase of the density of states projected on the nearest surface atom, p,, ( e), in the energy region of the it resonance, implying an electron donation from it to the surface. In the region near the Fermi level, the surface den- sity of states is dominated by s states and conse- quently the charge transfer to the it~ is mainly of s character. The approximate evaluation of the rela- tive contributions of s and d character are shown in 4. Conclusions In this work we have studied the chemisorbed mo- lecular state of oxygen on two metal substrates, Cu (100) and Ni (100). The results indicate that there are some important parameters which determine the charge transfer, In a typical geometry of the chemisorbed mole- cule, the interaction is strong, in particular with the d band. The different position of the d band on the energy scale for Cu and Ni determines the details of the charge transfer. For 02/Cu( 100) the d it interaction is stronger in comparison with 02/Ni (100), which will lead to a smaller occupancy of the it state. The d_lt* interac- tion is stronger for 02/Ni(l00), in comparison with 02/Cu(l00), as the it ' state is located near to the d band in the former case, while above the d band in the latter. This will lead to less charge transfer (metal to molecule) for 02/Ni( 100). The experimentally observed empty states of it character for 02/Pt( 111) [15] is possibly caused by an even stronger d it in- teraction compared to 02/Ni(l00), which might split part of the it ' resonance above the Fermi level. As the n~ resonance is located just below the Fermi level, the metal d electrons are most important in the charge transfer for Ni, while the metal s electrons dominate for Cu. The consequences of the overall charge transfer is that the bond order of the 0 0 bond is smaller for 02/Cu(lOO) compared to 02/Ni(l0O). This is in qualitative agreement with the observed difference in the redshift of the vibrational frequency of the ox- ygen internal stretch mode, when chemisorbed on some noble metal and transition-metal substrates [7 table I. 3.2. 02/Ni(100) In the case of Ni, the d band is located to higher energies. This will result in less d a hybridization and consequently only a minor perturbation of the it state. From the bottom pan of fig. 2 the hybridization of the it state is obviously stronger, as the it ' resonance appears right at the position of the free surfaced band (see Po(€) in the upper part of fig. 3). In addition, as the it ' resonance is located just below the Fermi level, part of the states might be pushed up above the Fermi level, which will further reduce the charge transfer. For Ni (100) this tendency is clear by the appearance of a peak just below the Fermi level. An important result, when comparing with earlier calculations of the system O2JNi (100) [17], is that the d electrons are certainly important in the charge transfer (see table 1). This is reasonable from a physical point of view if we consider the density of states (see lower part of fig. 3). The it~ resonance coincides with the d band, causing a strong d itt hy- bridization as the d density of states exceeds the sp density of states in this energy region. The same den- sity of states argument has been used to explain the strong 2p (oxygen) 4s,4p (nickel) hybridization when atomic oxygen is chemisorbed, 0/Ni( 100) [21]. In that case, the 2p resonance is well below the d band where the interaction with the 4s,4p band dominates. 9,11]. Acknowledgement We thank B.I. Lundqvist and B. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The chemisorbed state of molecular oxygen on Cu(100) and Ni(100) is investigated using a semi-empirical embedded cluster scheme. The antibonding π* orbital of oxygen will gain charge corresponding to almost complete filling of this state, predominantly by substrate s and d electrons for Cu and NI, respectively. For Ni, the charge transfer to π* is less efficient as the hybridization with the d band is stronger. Furthermore, the d—π hybridization reduces the occupancy of the bonding π state, in particular for Cu, for which this hybridization is stronger. Our results are consistent with experimental observations.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Interaction of atoms and molecules with solid surfaces
Electronic structure and the properties of solids
